text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a complete reprint with changes to IRM 9.7.4.
All references to the Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (EOAF) is changed to the Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF).
Subsection 9.7.4.3.5 is further revised, with subsection 9.7.4.3.5.1 to update the process for requesting approval for Title 18 forfeitures.
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, which did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity.

) Pre-seizure planning consists of anticipating and making intelligent about what property should be seized, how and when it should be seized, and most important, whether it should be seized. (

) Pre-seizure planning should occur, in both civil and criminal seizure and ture actions, prior to the actual physical seizure of property, and prior to the filing of a civil judicial forfeiture complaint or an indictment with a forfeiture count or allegation. (

) This section sets forth practices to minimize or avoid the possibility that Criminal Investigation (CI) and the Department of the Treasury will unnecessarily difficult or insurmountable problems in the seizure, and disposition of seized assets. (

) The Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) is responsible for ensuring proper and timely pre-seizure planning occurs in civil judicial and criminal feiture actions. In administrative forfeiture actions, the Asset Forfeiture Coordinator (AFC) has this responsibility. (

) Although the AUSA may be ultimately responsible for pre-seizure planning civil judicial and criminal forfeiture actions, the AFC is responsible for the pre-seizure planning process set forth in this section and ensuring that they are followed in all seizure and forfeiture actions. (

) Most importantly, it is the investigating agent’s responsibility to inform the of any potential seizure or forfeiture action as early as possible, so the AFC can ensure that timely and proper pre-seizure planning occurs. (
